reg:regulation.reg:title: Fort St. John Pilot Project Regulation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act;

applicable performance standard means the specific level to which a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence must perform a requirement of this regulation determined in decreasing order of priority as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as specified in a higher level plan unless the higher level plan

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was in effect less than 4 months before the submission for approval of a sustainable forest management plan or forest development plan for the area that specifically addressed the standard of performance, and
does not otherwise specify that the higher level plan is to prevail despite any sustainable forest management plan or forest development plan;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as specified in a variance with respect to the standard of performance;
as specified in a sustainable forest management plan unless a forest development plan

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was approved for the area before the sustainable forest management plan was approved for the area, and
specifically addressed the standard of performance;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as specified in the forest development plan;
as specified in a site level plan referred to in section 9;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: coniferous area means an area that under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 583/2004, s. 1 (a).]
a forest development plan, or
a forest operations schedule

bcl:definition.bcl:text: is to be reforested as a coniferous stand, in accordance with the reforestation regime that under section 32 applies;
coniferous stand means an area in which, at rotation age, the coniferous trees, collectively, represent a minimum of 80% of the net merchantable volume of timber on the area;
cutblock includes an area of land, other than a road right of way,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identified in a forest development plan referred to in section 12, in a forest operations schedule or in a site level plan, for areas in which timber harvesting is to be carried out,
identified in a site level plan that pertains to an area on which a contravention of section 96 of the Act has occurred and the area is to be reforested, or
referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), for which the district manager has exempted the participant from the requirement to prepare the forest development plan or site level plan as the case may be;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: crop tree means a healthy tree that is of a species that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ecologically suitable for the site, and
commercially valuable;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: deciduous area means an area that under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 583/2004, s. 1 (a).]
a forest development plan, or
a forest operations schedule

bcl:definition.bcl:text: is to be reforested as a deciduous stand, in accordance with the reforestation regime under section 32 that applies;
deciduous stand means an area in which, at rotation age, the deciduous trees, collectively, represent a minimum of 80% of the net merchantable volume of timber on the area;

designated environmental official means a person employed in the Ministry of Water, Land and Air Protection who is designated by name or title to be a designated environmental official by the minister of that ministry for the purpose of a provision of this regulation that is set out in the designation;
fisheries-sensitive zone means a flooded depression, pond or swamp, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: either perennially or seasonally contains water, and
is seasonally occupied by a species of fish listed in the definition of "fish stream" in the Operational and Site Planning Regulation,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include a wetland or lake that has a riparian management area established under Schedule D or a stream;
greened-up means greened-up under Schedule E;
harvested area means the area in a cutblock, other than that which is occupied by permanent access structures, in which timber harvesting has occurred;
holder of a minor timber sale licence means a person described in section 3 (1) (f);
known, when used to describe a feature, objective or other thing referred to in this regulation as known, means a feature, objective or other thing that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contained in a higher level plan, or

otherwise identified or made available to a participant by the district manager at least 4 months before the forest development plan, forest operations schedule or site level plan for the area was prepared;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: landscape level strategy means those activities that are required to be undertaken in order to achieve forest management objectives identified in a sustainable forest management plan;
minor timber sale licence means a timber sale licence that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizes harvesting of timber in the pilot area, and
is not a major licence;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mixedwood area means an area that under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 583/2004, s. 1 (a).]
a forest development plan, or
a forest operations schedule

bcl:definition.bcl:text: is to be reforested as a mixedwood stand, in accordance with the reforestation regime that under section 32 applies;
mixedwood stand means an area in which, at rotation age,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the coniferous trees, collectively, and
the deciduous trees, collectively,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: each represent a minimum of 20% of the net merchantable volume of timber on the area;
participant means the timber sales manager and a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is referred to in section 3 (1) (a) to (e) and has consented in writing to take part in the pilot project, or
becomes a participant under section 6 and has consented in writing to take part in the pilot project;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: performance indicator means a measurable variable that is specified in a sustainable forest management plan and is used to report progress toward the achievement of a goal;
permanent access structure means a road, landing, logging trail, pit, quarry or other similar structure in a cutblock that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is constructed by a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence and is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: required to be used for timber harvesting or other forest management activities and whose use will continue long enough to prevent the production of a commercial crop of trees on the area occupied by the structure that will be harvestable concurrently with the crop of adjacent trees, or

either constructed through material that is not suitable, or contains materials that are not suitable, for use in carrying out the soil rehabilitation treatments necessary to grow a commercial crop of trees, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: was constructed by a person other than a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pilot project means the Fort St. John pilot project, proposed by the participants, that is the subject of this regulation;
pilot project area means the Fort St. John Timber Supply Area;
public advisory group means a public advisory group established under section 46;
qualified auditor means a person who is competent to assess compliance with this regulation;
qualified registered professional means, with respect to an activity for which this regulation requires a qualified registered professional, a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has the education and experience that is appropriate to carry out the activity, and
is a member of, or licensed by, a regulatory body in British Columbia that has the legislated authority to regulate its members or licensees carrying out the activity;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: reforest means to establish on a harvested area a well-growing stand in accordance with section 32 or with a sustainable forest management plan, whichever of them is applicable;
regional director means a regional director employed in the Ministry of Water, Land and Air Protection;
rehabilitate means to restore to a stable condition and to a condition that does not prevent the reforestation requirement from being met;

resource agencies means any government agency, ministry or department having jurisdiction over a resource that may be affected by any activity or operation proposed under a higher level plan or plan required under this regulation;
riparian class means the riparian class determined under Schedule D;
riparian management area means an area of a width determined in accordance with Schedule D that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is adjacent to a stream or wetland or a lake with a riparian class of L3, and
consists of a riparian management zone and, depending on the riparian class of the stream, wetland or lake, a riparian reserve zone;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: riparian management zone means that portion of the riparian management area that is outside of any riparian reserve zone or if there is no riparian reserve zone, that area located adjacent to a stream, wetland or lake of a width determined in accordance with Schedule D;

riparian reserve zone means that portion, if any, of the riparian management area or lakeshore management area located adjacent to a stream, wetland or lake of a width determined in accordance with Schedule D;
site level plan means a site level plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: referred to in section 9 or 10, or
required under Part 3, Division 3;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: small business forest enterprise program means the government program administered by the Ministry of Forests that facilitates the entering into agreements under the Forest Act that generate small business forest enterprise revenue;

sustaining soil productivity means ensuring that, at the conclusion of harvesting operations in a cutblock, the capacity of the site to produce stands of timber is not less than the preharvest capacity of the site to produce stands of timber;
timber sales manager means timber sales manager as defined in section 1 (1) of the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Words and expressions used in this regulation that are not defined in the Act or this regulation have the meaning given to them in the Operational and Site Planning Regulation and the Tree Cone, Seed and Vegetative Material Regulation.
Distances referred to in this regulation are horizontal distances except for the distances referred to in Schedule D, which are slope distances.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special circumstances when Crown timber may be cut, etc.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 96 (1) of the Act, a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence is authorized to cut, damage or destroy Crown timber in the course of fire control or suppression operations.

For the purposes of section 96 (1) (f.1) of the Act, a participant is authorized to cut, damage or destroy Crown timber on an area if the cutting, damaging or destruction of the timber happens in the course of carrying out silviculture treatments, stand tending treatments, forest health treatments, or any other activity that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ancillary to the purposes of the Act,
authorized by the district manager, or
funded under the Forest Investment Vote in the estimates of the ministry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 96 (1) (g) (iii) of the Act, this regulation, the Workers Compensation Act and the regulations under that Act are prescribed enactments.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inapplicable provisions of the Act and regulations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of the pilot project, the enactments listed in subsection (4) do not apply to each of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Canadian Forest Products Ltd. as the holder of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: forest licence A 18154, and
pulpwood agreement 12;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Canadian Forest Products Ltd. and West Moberly First Nation, as the holder of forest licence A56771;
Cameron River Logging Ltd., as the holder of forest licence A59959;
Tembec Inc., as the holder of forest licence A60972;
Louisiana-Pacific Canada Limited, as the holder of forest licences A60049 and A60050;
each person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is the holder of a timber sale licence that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: authorizes harvesting of timber in the pilot area, and
is not a major licence, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has consented to participate in the pilot project;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an agreement holder, referred to in paragraphs (a) to (f), as the holder of a road permit associated with the agreement;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 12/2010, s. 2 (a).]

a holder of a pulpwood agreement, referred to in paragraph (a), as the holder of a forestry licence to cut entered into under section 47.6 of the Forest Act, to satisfy the obligations of the government under the pulpwood agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of the pilot project,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the enactments listed in subsection (4) do not apply in relation to the district manager of the Peace Forest District, to the timber sales manager or to the government, and
this regulation applies in respect of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a road that is constructed after the effective date of this regulation for the primary purpose of providing access to timber to be harvested under a minor timber sale licence, and
a road that was constructed before the effective date of this regulation if

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the road has not been permanently deactivated, and
the district manager is satisfied that the primary purpose of the road when it was constructed was to provide access to timber to be harvested under the small business forest enterprise program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 350/2002, Sch. E, s. 1.]
The following are the listed enactments referred to in subsections (1) and (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 3 of the Act;
Part 4 of the Act, except sections 50 to 52 and sections 66 and 69 of the Act;
the Operational and Site Planning Regulation, except sections 1, 69, 70 and 71 of that regulation;
the Forest Road Regulation;
the Timber Harvesting and Silviculture Practices Regulation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 350/2002, Sch. E, s. 1.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of the pilot project, a provision of the Forest Act, an agreement under the Forest Act, the Forest and Range Practices Act or the regulations under either the Forest Act or the Forest and Range Practices Act that requires the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act or a timber sales manager

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to prepare a forest stewardship plan or a site plan or to perform a requirement in relation to a forest stewardship plan or site plan does not apply to a participant if the participant prepares a sustainable forest management plan, forest operations schedule and site level plan under this regulation, and

for a road or cutblock, to obtain a road permit or cutting permit does not apply to a participant if the participant receives an authorization from the district manager under section 23 for that road or cutblock.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 3.]
For the balancing of competing values and interests for the purposes of section 221.1 (5) of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are established in the pilot project area the 24 management zones that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: named under column 1 in items 1 to 24 of Part A1 of Schedule A, under the heading "Management Zones and Their Objectives", and
shown in the map set out in Part A2 of Schedule A under the heading "Fort St. John Pilot Project Management Zone Map", and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the objectives for each management zone named under column 1 of an item of Part A1 of Schedule A are the objectives set out in that item under column 2 of Part A1 of that schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A holder of an agreement under the Forest Act who carries out forest practices in the pilot project area may apply in writing to the regional manager to become a participant.
On receiving an application under subsection (1), the regional manager must publish notice of the application in a newspaper published in the pilot project area.
The regional manager may approve an application under subsection (1) only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of the application is consistent with subsection (4), and
the regional manager has considered any comments received in writing within 3 weeks after the date of publication of the notice under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The pilot project is exempt from the requirements of section 221.1 (4) (a) of the Act on the condition that the pilot project not account for more than 12% of the total of all allowable cuts in effect in the Prince George forest region on July 15, 1999.
A participant may apply in writing to the regional manager to cease to be a participant.
The regional manager may approve an application under subsection (1) only if satisfied that doing so will not result in material economic hardship to the other participants.
An approval under subsection (2) may be made subject to conditions.
An approval that is subject to conditions under subsection (3) does not take effect until the regional manager is satisfied that the conditions have been fulfilled.
If the holder of an agreement who has ceased to be a participant because of an approval under this section has commenced

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvesting timber in a cutblock, or
construction of a road

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: this regulation, despite the approval, continues to apply to that holder with respect to the holder's obligations for the cutblock or road.
If the timber sales manager has ceased to be a participant because of an approval under this section and a holder of a minor timber sale licence has commenced

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvesting timber in a cutblock, or
construction of a road,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: this regulation, despite the approval, continues to apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the timber sales manager with respect to the government's obligations for the cutblock or road, and
the holder of the minor timber sale licence with respect to the holder's obligations for the cutblock and road.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The district manager may extend the term of a forest development plan of a participant until December 31, 2005.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A silviculture prescription must be treated under this regulation as a site level plan referred to in section 16 if the silviculture prescription was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approved by the district manager under section 41 of the Act, or
given effect by the district manager under section 40 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), a participant must comply with Part 3 Division 5 when carrying out operations on the area of a site level plan referred to in subsection (1).
In respect of a site level plan referred to in subsection (1), if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the site level plan contains a performance requirement for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a proportion of the cutblock area that may be occupied by permanent access structures that is higher than the proportion specified in section 30 (1),
a reforestation period that is longer than specified in section 32 (4),
a stocking requirement that is lower than those specified in section 32 (5), or
an attribute of a well-growing crop tree that is less restrictive than that specified in section 32 (6), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the commencement date under section 70 of the Act did not occur before November 15, 2001,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: then the applicable performance requirement under this regulation for the area is that higher proportion, longer period, lower stocking requirement or less restrictive attribute, as the case may be.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Pre-existing cutting permits, road permits and road use permits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A cutting permit, road permit or road use permit that was in effect immediately before the effective date of this regulation must be treated under this regulation as an authorization of the district manager under section 23.
If an

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approved road layout and design associated with a cutting permit or road permit referred to in subsection (1), or
approved road deactivation prescription associated with a cutting permit, road permit or road use permit referred to in subsection (1)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: was in effect immediately before the effective date of this regulation, the approved road layout and design or approved road deactivation prescription must be treated under this regulation as a site level plan referred to in section 18.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 583/2004, s. 5.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to sections 8 and 45, a participant must not harvest timber under an agreement unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area to be harvested has been identified in a forest development plan that complies with Schedule B, and
the forest development plan has been approved under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to sections 8 and 45, the timber sales manager may not enter into a timber sale licence that generates revenue that is credited to the BC Timber Sales Account unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area to be harvested has been identified in a forest development plan that complies with Schedule B, and
the forest development plan has been approved under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may exempt a participant from subsection (1) or the timber sales manager from subsection (2) if the district manager determines that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the only timber to be harvested under the agreement is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the felling and removal of trees to eliminate a safety hazard,
the felling of trees to facilitate the collection of seed and the proposed harvesting will not result in an opening of greater than 1 ha,
the removal of trees that have already been felled, from landings and road rights of way,
the removal of trees from recreation sites or recreation trails, or
the felling and removal of trees that have been or will be treated to facilitate the entrapment of pests, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is no road construction required to provide access for harvesting of the timber.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: One or more participants may prepare and submit to the district manager for approval a single forest development plan.
A forest development plan referred to in subsection (4) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify which participant is responsible for each road and cutblock proposed on the plan, and
contain the signature of each participant who submitted the plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Approval of forest development plans or amendments

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is the holder of a forest development plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may prepare and submit to the district manager for approval an amendment to the plan at any time, or
if it is a plan to which section 20.2 applies, may amend the plan at any time, in accordance with that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager must approve a forest development plan submitted under this Part or an amendment to one if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan or the plan as amended was prepared and submitted in accordance with Schedule B, and
the district manager is satisfied that the plan or plan as amended will adequately manage and conserve the forest resources of the area to which it applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before approving a forest development plan or amendment, the district manager may require the participant to submit information that the district manager reasonably requires in order to determine if the plan or amendment complies with subsection (1).
The district manager may not approve a forest development plan or amendment unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it was prepared and submitted in accordance with Schedule B, and
the district manager is satisfied as set out in subsection (1) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may make the district manager's approval of a forest development plan or amendment subject to conditions.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 6.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest development plan approved under this Division for a participant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: takes effect on the date specified in the approval, and
expires 2 years after the date specified in the approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may extend the term of a forest development plan referred to in subsection (1) for a period or periods not exceeding one year in total.
If the term of a forest development plan is extended under subsection (2), the participant who prepared the plan must promptly amend the plan as necessary to ensure compliance with this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Site level plans required before timber harvesting or reforestation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The timber sales manager must prepare a site level plan for the following areas of Crown land:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cutblock, before the area is harvested under a minor timber sale licence;

an area in which the timber was cut, removed, damaged or destroyed in contravention of section 96 of the Act by a holder of a minor timber sale licence, as soon as is practicable after a determination has been made with respect to the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is the holder of an agreement under the Forest Act must prepare a site level plan for the following areas of Crown land:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cutblock, before the participant harvests timber in the cutblock area;

an area in which the timber was either cut, removed, damaged or destroyed in contravention of section 96 of the Act by the participant, as soon as is practicable after a determination has been made with respect to the contravention;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 7 (a).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may exempt a participant from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subsection (1) (a) or (2) (a) if the area to be harvested in the cutblock does not exceed 2 ha and is not adjacent to an area for which a previous exemption was granted, unless that area has become well-growing, or
subsection (1) (b) or (2) (b) if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the area in which the contravention occurred is less than 1 ha, and
the district manager considers that a site level plan is not necessary to facilitate the adequate management and conservation of the forest resources on the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 7 (c).]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 8.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Site level plans required before construction, modification or deactivation of roads
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant must prepare a site level plan for an area in which a road is to be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructed or modified, or
deactivated

bcl:section.bcl:text: before commencement of the construction, modification or deactivation, as the case may be.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that a site level plan referred to in section 16

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is signed and sealed by a professional forester,
is consistent with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any forest development plan in effect for the area at the time the site level plan is prepared, or
if there is no forest development plan in effect for the area,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the sustainable forest management plan in effect at the time the site level plan is prepared, and
the forest operations schedule that applies to the area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes a map showing the location of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the cutblock,
any resource features and mappable reserves in the cutblock, and
the approximate location of roads in the cutblock,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes the information the professional forester determines necessary for the professional forester to have reasonable grounds to believe that the participant will comply with Division 5 if forest practices are carried out in accordance with the site level plan, and
is signed by the participant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that a site level plan referred to in section 18

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is prepared by a qualified registered professional unless, with respect to a site level plan referred to in section 18 (b), the participant has determined that the area has a low likelihood of landslides,
is consistent with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any forest development plan in effect for the area at the time the site level plan is prepared, or
if there is no forest development plan in effect for the area,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the sustainable forest management plan in effect at the time the site level plan is prepared, and
the forest operations schedule that applies to the area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes a map showing the approximate location of the road,

includes the information the preparer determines necessary for the preparer to have reasonable grounds to believe that the participant will comply with Division 5 if the road is constructed or deactivated in accordance with the site level plan, and
is signed by the participant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant may amend a site level plan and, if so, must ensure that the amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complies with the relevant requirements of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: subsection (1), if it is an amendment to a site level plan referred to in section 16, or
subsection (2), if it is an amendment to a site level plan referred to in section 18, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is signed by the participant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notification of site level plans and of amendments to them

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section site level plan review period means the 30 day period commencing on the date the district manager receives the notice referred to in subsection (4).

The district manager may specify cutblocks and roads for which, under subsection (4), the participant must give notice of a site level plan associated with the cutblock or road or of an amendment to such a site level plan if the district manager does so by notice given to the participant,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when a forest development plan is approved, or
within 14 days after the participant submits to the district manager the information required after the forest operations schedule is made available for review and comment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may establish policies for matters not addressed in Schedules E and F, describing circumstances in addition to those under subsection (2), in which the participant must give notice under subsection (4) if a site level plan or amendment to a site level plan is inconsistent with the policies.

A participant must give notice to the district manager of a site level plan or an amendment to a site level plan if the district manager has required the participant to provide notice of the plan or amendment under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice under subsection (2), or
a policy referred to in subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any time during the site level plan review period, the district manager may require a participant to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refer a site level plan or amendment to a site level plan to resource agencies specified by the district manager, and
provide copies of one or more of the assessments, that are related to the site level plan or amendment to the site level plan, to the resource agencies specified by the district manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review all written comments received from resource agencies during the site level plan review period,
make any revisions to the site level plan or amendment to the site level plan that the participant considers appropriate, and
submit to the district manager

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of each written comment received under paragraph (a), and
a summary of all revisions made under paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If within

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 5 days after receiving a submission from the participant under subsection (6), or
the site level plan review period if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: no referral was requested under subsection (5), or
no written comments were received by the participant as a result of the referral process,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the district manager determines that the operations described in the site level plan or amendment to the site level plan will not adequately manage and conserve the forest resources of the area affected by the plan, the district manager may notify the participant in writing that the participant must not carry out on the area under the site level plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any forest practices, or
one or more specified forest practices.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under subsection (7) must include the rationale for the district manager's determination under that subsection.
A participant who is required to give notice of a site level plan or amendment to a site level plan under this section must not carry out,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if notified by the district manager under subsection (7), the forest practice or forest practices to which the notice applies, until being advised by the district manager that the forest practice or forest practices may proceed, or
in another case, any forest practice on the area that is subject to the site level plan or amendment, until the earlier of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date of expiry of the period in which the district manager may make a determination under subsection (7), and
the date of being advised by the district manager that the operations may proceed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section does not apply to a site level plan referred to in section 9 but does apply to an amendment to such a site level plan if the site level plan does not contain an applicable performance standard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amending a site level plan under section 9 that contains an applicable performance standard

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is the holder of a site level plan referred to in section 9 that contains an applicable performance standard

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may prepare and submit to the district manager for approval an amendment to the plan at any time, or
if it is a plan to which section 20.2 applies, may amend the plan at any time, in accordance with that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager must approve an amendment to a site level plan under subsection (1) (a) if the district manager is satisfied that the plan as amended will adequately manage and conserve the forest resources of the area to which the plan pertains.

Before approving an amendment under this section, the district manager may require the participant to submit information that the district manager reasonably requires to determine if the amendment complies with subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendments to specified plans that do not require approval

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 20.3, an approval is not required to amend

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan, or
a site level plan referred to in section 9 that contains an applicable performance standard

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if the holder of the plan considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposed amendment does not materially change the intended results or strategies specified in the plan, or
the proposed amendment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: will not increase the adverse impact on forest resources, and
conforms to the circumstances specified in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The circumstances for the purposes of subsection (1) (d) (ii) are:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deletions of previously approved cutblocks or roads, provided that the implementation of the amendment will not deleteriously impact forest health on the area;
changes, as a result of a traverse that was more accurate than the traverse that was previously carried out on an area, in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the location of a cutblock or road, or
the area of a cutblock after harvesting in the cutblock has been completed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: changes in the year or season of harvest or road building, provided that the timing is not critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
changes in proposed roads, including temporary roads, provided that the changes maintain the general pattern and intent of proposed road development access;
increases in the size of a cutblock provided that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount of the increase does not exceed

bcl:clause.bcl:text: 1 ha or 25%, whichever is greater, if the cutblock is less than 20 ha, or
10 ha or 25%, whichever is less, if the cutblock is at least 20 ha,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the cutblock size remains consistent with section 65, and
none of the area being added to the cutblock as a result of the proposed amendment will result in harvesting within

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a riparian management zone of a stream that has a classification of S1, S2, S3 or S4,
a known forest ecosystem network,
a wildlife tree patch,
a known old growth management area, or
a known ungulate winter range;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: changes in the silvicultural system from a clearcut system to a partial cut system;
changes to harvesting systems from ground to aerial or cable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A holder of a forest development plan or a site level plan that is amended under this section must provide a copy of the amendment to the district manager on request.
A holder of a forest development plan or a site level plan who makes an amendment under this section need not make the amendment available for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review, and
comment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: District manager actions if amendments wrongly made

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may take the action specified in this section, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the holder of a forest development plan or a site level plan has made an amendment to the plan under section 20.2 without the approval of the district manager, and
the district manager considers that the determination by the holder that the amendment met the requirements of that section was wrongly made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager, in a written notice to the holder who made the amendment referred to in subsection (1), may order the holder to suspend any operations on the area that are subject to the amendment to the extent that the operations are materially affected by the amendment.
An order under subsection (2) remains in effect until the earlier of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of the amendment, and
the district manager rescinding the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amendment made under section 20.2 that is subject to an order under subsection (2) is without effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Where amendments may not be made without approval
bcl:section.bcl:text: A holder of a site level plan or forest development plan may not make an amendment to the plan under section 20.2 (1) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the holder has been subject to an order under section 20.3 (2) and the order remains in effect under section 20.3 (3),
the amendment is with respect to the regeneration date, the free growing assessment period or the stocking requirements,
the amendment increases the limits for the amount of permanent access structures permitted under section 30 (1),
the amendment increases the limits for the amount of soil disturbance specified in the plan, if any, or
the amendment reduces the retention of wildlife trees or wildlife tree patches.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant must carry out an archaeological impact assessment in accordance with the requirements of the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act before carrying out a forest practice on an area, if the district manager is satisfied that the assessment is necessary to adequately manage and conserve archaeological sites in the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence must not harvest or remove Crown timber or carry out road construction, modification or deactivation operations unless authorized to do so under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this regulation,
an agreement under the Forest Act, or
the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence must not use a road on Crown land, other than a road that is subject to the Transportation Act, Land Act or Local Government Act, for the purposes of timber harvesting and related purposes unless authorized to do so under this regulation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 12.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: District manager may authorize timber harvesting and road construction

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 23.1, at any time, a participant may submit to the district manager a request for an authorization under this section.
The district manager must not give an authorization for one or more cutblocks and roads unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cutblock or road was identified in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan in effect for the area, or
a forest operations schedule that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: complies with section 45, and
was made available for public review and comment in accordance with Schedule C, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the district manager is satisfied that the proposed cutblocks or roads for which the authorization is sought are identified in an acceptable form and scale.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may refuse to give an authorization for a cutblock or road if the district manager has reasonable grounds to believe that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: giving the authorization would infringe a treaty right, or
the forest operations proposed in the area of the proposed cutblock or road would not comply with Division 5.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information required before requesting an authorization

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before or at the time of requesting an authorization under section 23 in respect of a cutblock that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a Category A cutblock

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: identified in a forest development plan referred to in section 8, and
for which there is no silviculture prescription described in section 9 (1), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is described in section 81 (1) (i) and identified in a forest operations schedule,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: a participant, for the purposes of section 32 and Schedule F, must submit written notice to the district manager of whether the participant proposes to reforest an area within the cutblock as a coniferous area, a deciduous area or a mixedwood area.

After receipt of notice under subsection (1) or (5) the district manager, if satisfied that reforestation as proposed will adequately manage and conserve the forest resources of the area, may approve the proposal.

If not satisfied that reforestation as proposed will adequately manage and conserve the forest resources of the area, the district manager, within 14 days after receipt of notice under subsection (1) or (5), may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refuse to approve the proposal, and
give notice of the refusal to the participant, giving the reasons for the refusal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the district manager does not, within the time limit of 14 days referred to in subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approve the proposal, or
refuse to approve the proposal and give notice of the refusal to the participant,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the participant is deemed on the expiry of that time limit of 14 days to have received the district manager's approval under subsection (2) to the proposal.
A participant who receives notice under subsection (3) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: modify the participant's proposal under subsection (1) to the satisfaction of the district manager, and
submit the modified proposal to the district manager for approval under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 32 and Schedule F, a participant who has received the district manager's approval under subsection (2) must ensure that reforestation is carried out in accordance with the proposal that is the subject of the approval.
A participant may submit to the district manager an amendment to a proposal under this section and this section applies in respect of the amendment.

Despite anything to the contrary in an agreement or an authorization, an authorization given under section 23, before or after the coming into force of this section, is effective on the date it is given and expires

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if it is an authorization to harvest a cutblock, on the later to occur of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 4 years after the effective date, and
March 31, 2007, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if it is an authorization for a road, when the participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence, as the case may be, has complied with section 31 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), if notified by the district manager, a participant must not commence harvesting under an authorization

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a block or group of blocks, or
in a road right of way

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: until after the participant submits appraisal data required for the determination of a stumpage rate.

If satisfied that an extension will not have a deleterious impact on the forest resources in the area to which an authorization to harvest a cutblock pertains, the district manager may grant one or more extensions to the authorization, each for a period not to exceed 2 years, with the first extension beginning on the expiry date referred to in subsection (1) (a) applicable to that authorization.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 360/2006, s. 1 (b).]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority of the district manager to vary a performance requirement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant may submit to the district manager, at any time, a request for a variance under this section.
A request for a variance must specify all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area in the pilot project area for which the variance is requested;
the requirement of this regulation to which the variance relates;
the proposed performance requirement, including whether it is to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide relief from a requirement of Division 5,
establish an applicable performance standard for the purposes of Division 5, or
provide a variance from a performance requirement established under section 42;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a rationale for making the request.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may give a variance only if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: implementing the variance will adequately manage and conserve the forest resources on the area affected by the application, or
the variance is necessary for the safety of the public.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may not give a variance to a participant to perform a forest practice that is inconsistent with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 28 (1) (d) or (g) (iv), or
section 100 (d) of Schedule F.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may make a variance subject to conditions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compliance with notices, authorizations, conditions and variances
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant must comply with any notice, authorization, condition or variance given by the district manager under this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division is subject to section 42.
A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence does not contravene a requirement of this Division if, with respect to the requirement, the participant is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: acting in accordance with a variance, or
carrying out fire control or suppression in accordance with the Act and the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (1) and (2), this Division applies to any forest practice carried out on the pilot project area by a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence and includes areas where harvesting or road construction or modification began on or after November 15, 2001.
A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who carries out a forest practice on an area must ensure that the forest practice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is consistent with any sustainable forest management plan, forest development plan and site level plan,
does not result in any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the felling or modifying of trees in an area that is

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a riparian reserve zone except at a stream crossing for a road, or
a reserve identified in a site level plan;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: damage to any resource feature;
equipment fueling and servicing fluids damaging forest resources;
the harvesting of areas adjacent to areas that are not greened-up except as permitted under Schedule E,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the area is a known scenic area, is consistent with any established visual quality objectives for the area,
if the area is a known wildlife habitat area, is consistent with known general wildlife measures that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: established for application in the wildlife habitat area, and
made available to the participant by the district manager or designated environmental official at the time the wildlife habitat area is made known,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conserves the soil by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: maintaining slope stability,
maintaining surface drainage patterns, and
minimizing surface soil erosion,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protects the productive capacity of harvested areas, by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: sustaining soil productivity,
rehabilitating compacted areas, and
rehabilitating areas occupied by access structures if the rehabilitation is necessary to sustain soil productivity, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protects water quality, water quantity, fish and fish habitat by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: maintaining shade over known temperature sensitive streams,
providing for safe passage of fish in streams for the purposes of spawning, rearing or migration,
maintaining fisheries-sensitive zones,

complying with any timing windows and measures established by a designated environmental official to adequately manage and conserve aquatic resources that apply to forest practices in and around streams, unless relieved of that requirement by the designated environmental official,

protecting stream bank and stream channel stability, including minimizing or mitigating stream bank and stream channel disturbances at any crossing or immediately upstream or downstream from that crossing,
minimizing sediment entering into streams, and
protecting the structural integrity of any associated road and drainage structures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carries out a forest practice, and
knows that the carrying out of that forest practice contravenes subsection (1)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must take reasonable measures to mitigate any damage to the environment resulting directly or indirectly from that contravention.
Subsection (1) (f) (i) does not apply to an area to which section 30.1 pertains.
A participant must ensure that the total area in cutblocks that is occupied by wildlife trees or wildlife tree patches is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least the total area in cutblocks specified in the applicable performance standard for wildlife tree or wildlife tree patches, or
if there is not an applicable performance standard, for each calendar year, at least 4% of the total area of the cutblocks in which harvesting was completed during the calendar year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that the total amount of coarse woody debris located on cutblocks in which harvesting is complete is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least the total amount for cutblocks specified in the applicable performance standard for retention of coarse woody debris, or

if there is not an applicable performance standard, for each calendar year, at least 50% of the estimated total amount of pre-harvest coarse woody debris remains among the cutblocks in which harvesting was completed that year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the end of timber harvesting operations in a cutblock, a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence must not cause the proportion of the cutblock area occupied by permanent access structures to exceed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, 7% of the total cutblock area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence, at the conclusion of using a permanent access structure that was constructed by the participant or holder, must deactivate the permanent access structure.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Soil disturbance for specified site level plans
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is the holder of a site level plan referred to in section 9 for an area for which subsection (3) of that section does not apply, and
carries out a forest practice on the area

bcl:section.bcl:text: must not exceed the maximum amount of soil disturbance within the net area to be reforested that is specified in the site level plan for the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who constructs a road must ensure that the road adequately provides for safe usage by the types and levels of traffic for which the road was intended.
A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructs or modifies a road, or
is authorized to use a road that is not subject to another authorization or permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must maintain the road until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is deactivated, or
the district manager notifies the participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence that the road is required by others and that use will preclude permanent deactivation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use a road that was constructed or modified by another participant, and
for a road referred to in paragraph (a), enter into agreements with that participant for road maintenance and deactivation of that road.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: commencement date means the date of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the commencement of harvesting in the cutblock, other than harvesting associated with roads and landings, and
the determination for areas in which there was a contravention of section 96 of the Act,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 16 (a).]

bcl:definition.bcl:text: overtopping vegetation means vegetation that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: taller than the crop tree,
within 1 m of the trunk of the crop tree, and
impedes the growth of the crop tree.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a participant is not required to reforest an area if the district manager

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has exempted the participant from the requirement to prepare a site level plan, or
determines that the nature and extent of harvesting operations on the area is limited to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: minor salvage operations, or
minor harvesting operations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant, in accordance with this section and Schedule F, must reforest

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvested areas if the participant is responsible for the harvesting or for authorizing the harvesting.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 292/2003, Sch. D, s. 16 (b).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: by establishing, during the reforestation period, a well-growing stand of crop trees that meets or exceeds the stocking requirements for the area.
For the purposes of subsection (3), the reforestation period is the period determined by moving forward from the commencement date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of years specified in the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, 15 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (3), the stocking requirements are that the stand of trees includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the silvicultural system is other than single tree selection, at least the minimum number of well-growing trees

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specified in the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: for coniferous areas and deciduous areas, determined in accordance with Table A in Schedule F, and
for mixedwood areas, established by the district manager, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the silvicultural system is single tree selection, for at least one layer of the stand, at least the minimum number of well-growing crop trees

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specified in the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, established by the district manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (3), a well-growing crop tree must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have achieved the minimum height for its species

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specified in the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, determined in accordance with Table A of Schedule F,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for coniferous areas, other than those described in paragraph (c), have no overtopping vegetation unless otherwise specified in the applicable performance standard,
for coniferous areas in which a brushing treatment has been carried out, have no overtopping vegetation as assessed at least

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 2 years following a chemical brushing treatment, or
3 years following a manual brushing treatment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless otherwise specified in the applicable performance standard,
be at least the following distance apart from the nearest crop tree:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, then

bcl:clause.bcl:text: 1.5 m for coniferous areas,
0.5 m for deciduous areas, and
0.75 m for mixedwood areas, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have been growing on the area for a period of time that is at least

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the specified applicable performance standard, or
if there is no applicable performance standard, 9 years from the commencement of harvesting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before establishing standards under subsection (5), the district manager must consult with the participants.
A participant who is required to reforest a cutblock must carry out silviculture regimes that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are designed to achieve target stocking specified in the applicable performance standard, or

if there is no applicable performance standard, are consistent with achieving the values for managed stand yield tables used by the chief forester in making the most recent annual allowable cut determination for the Fort St. John timber supply area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who uses trap trees or pheromones to concentrate insect populations must ensure that the insect brood is destroyed before the insects emerge.

The participants, within 2 years after the effective date of this regulation, must jointly submit a single sustainable forest management plan to the regional manager and regional director for approval in accordance with this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must ensure that the sustainable forest management plan required under section 34

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: addresses the entire pilot project area, and
is consistent with Schedule A and any higher level plan in effect in the pilot project area on the date the sustainable forest management plan is submitted for approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A sustainable forest management plan at a minimum must include landscape level strategies for all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: timber harvesting;
road access management;
patch size, seral stage distribution and adjacency;
riparian management;
visual quality management;
forest health management;
range and forage management.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A sustainable landscape level plan may also include strategies for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reforestation;
biodiversity management, including habitat management for wildlife;
soil management;
water quality management;
recreation management;
forest protection;
forest resource inventory;
research and operational trials;
public review and comment;
any other forest management attribute approved by the regional manager and regional director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must ensure that a sustainable forest management plan, for each landscape level strategy contained in the plan, specifies the performance indicators for evaluating whether or not the strategy has been successfully implemented.
The participants must ensure that the sustainable forest management plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specifies the provisions, if any, of Part 3 Division 5 and the Schedules that are to be affected through the application of the proposed landscape level strategy, and
includes a rationale on how the proposed landscape level strategy will

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide at least equivalent protection for forest resources and resource features as that provided in the provisions referred to in paragraph (a),
be consistent with the preamble to the Act, and
provide for adequate management and conservation of forest resources.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must ensure that the sustainable forest management plan includes any applicable performance standards that are to be used for the purposes of Part 3 Division 5 and the associated Schedules.
The sustainable forest management plan must be signed by each participant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 37 and 38 do not apply to an amendment of an administrative nature to a sustainable forest management plan or to an amendment that does not materially change the objectives or results of the plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Public advisory group review and comment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must ensure that a proposed sustainable forest management plan is submitted to the public advisory group for review and comment before a notice is published under section 38 (1).
The public advisory group that receives a proposed sustainable forest management plan under subsection (1) may make written comments and recommendations for improvement that it considers appropriate.
The participants must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider all comments and recommendations received under subsection (2), and
notify the public advisory group on how the recommendations were addressed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving a notice under subsection (3), the public advisory group must specify in writing whether or not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the recommendations of the group under subsection (2) have been adequately addressed by the participants, and
any concerns have arisen as a result of changes made to the proposed sustainable forest management plan since it was initially reviewed by the group.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must append the comments of the public advisory group received under subsections (2) and (4) to the sustainable forest management plan when the plan is submitted to the regional manager and regional director under section 38 (1) (b).
Before the participants submit a sustainable forest management plan for approval, the participants must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: publish a notice, in a form acceptable to the regional manager, in a newspaper stating that the sustainable forest management plan is available for public review and comment,
submit to the regional manager and regional director a copy of the proposed sustainable forest management plan in the form that will be made available for review

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at substantially the same time as a person first publishes the notice referred to in paragraph (a), or
at any other time agreed to by the regional manager and the participants, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the request of the regional manager or regional director, submit to the regional manager or regional director, as the case may be, a copy of any assessments associated with any landscape level strategies contained in the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must provide an opportunity to review a proposed sustainable forest management plan to members of the public interested in or affected by operations under the proposed plan.

If an assessment is required as part of a landscape level strategy specified in the proposed sustainable forest management plan, the participants, on the request of a person conducting a review of the plan, must make the assessment available for viewing to that person to assist their review of the plan.

Unless otherwise specified by the regional manager, the opportunity for a review under subsection (2) must be for a period of at least 90 days beginning on the date of the publication referred to in subsection (1).
During the period referred to in subsection (4), a person who reviews a proposed sustainable forest management plan under this section may submit written comments to the participants.

The participants must consider all written comments received under subsection (5) and may make any revisions to the proposed sustainable forest management plan that the participants consider appropriate.
The participants who submit a sustainable forest management plan to the regional manager and regional director for approval must submit with the proposed plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the notice published under subsection (1),
a copy of each written comment received under subsection (5), and
a summary of all revisions made to the proposed plan under subsection (6).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional manager and regional director must approve a sustainable forest management plan or amendment if the regional manager and regional director are satisfied that the plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is consistent with the content requirements of this regulation,
is consistent with the preamble to the Act,
provides at least the equivalent protection for forest resources and resource features as that provided by the Act and its regulations, and
adequately manages and conserves the forest resources on those portions of the pilot project area that are affected by the proposed strategies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the regional manager and regional director are not satisfied that a proposed sustainable forest management plan or amendment complies with subsection (1), the regional manager and regional director may approve portions of the plan or amendment that they are satisfied do comply and may make that approval subject to conditions.

An approval of a sustainable forest management plan or amendment under subsection (1) or (2) is valid for a term of 6 years beginning on the effective date of the approval unless the participants request a shorter period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Extension of term of sustainable forest management plan
bcl:section.bcl:text: The regional manager and regional director by written notice given to the participant may extend the term of a sustainable forest management plan, before or after it expires, for an additional period not exceeding 2 years.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Effect of Approval of Sustainable Forest Management Plan

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of approval on operational plans

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The approval of a sustainable forest management plan does not affect any

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: forest development plan or amendment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: referred to in section 8, or
approved under this regulation before the approval of a sustainable forest management plan, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: site level plan or amendment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: referred to in section 9, or
prepared in accordance with this regulation before the approval of the sustainable forest management plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who amends a forest development plan that was approved before a sustainable forest management plan was approved is not required to ensure that the amendment is consistent with the sustainable forest management plan for the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of approval on permits and authorizations
bcl:section.bcl:text: The approval of a sustainable forest management plan does not affect any

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cutting permit, road permit or road use permit referred to in section 10, or
any authorization under section 23 given before the approval of the sustainable forest management plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of approval on performance requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: component area means an area

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is the subject of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan or forest operations schedule, and
a site level plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that are consistent with the applicable sustainable forest management plan,
for which a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence is exempt from section 12, 16 or 18, or
for which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: there is a site level plan referred to in section 9, and
the holder of the site level plan has submitted to the district manager a statement that the area is subject to the applicable sustainable forest management plan;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: specified means specified in the sustainable forest management plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If Division 5 of Part 3 conflicts or is inconsistent with this section, this section prevails.
For each component area, the responsible participant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: achieve the specified targets within the specified range of variance,
carry out forest operations in a manner consistent with the specified landscape level strategies,
ensure that stocking in coniferous areas in the component area conforms with the specified mean stocked quadrant value,
ensure that the retention of wildlife trees conforms with the specified wildlife tree retention requirements, and
ensure that the retention of coarse woody debris conforms with the specified coarse woody debris retention requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each component area on which the holder of a minor timber sale licence carries out forest operations, the holder must ensure that the operations are consistent with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the specified targets within the specified range of variance,
the specified landscape level strategies, and
the reforestation requirements described in section 32 and Schedule F.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants may apply to the regional manager and regional director at any time to amend a sustainable forest management plan.
An amendment to a sustainable forest management plan proposed under this section may address any aspect of the plan, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adding an additional landscape level strategy,
modifying an existing landscape level strategy, or
removing a landscape level strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amendment must comply with section 35 (4) to (6) with respect to the affected landscape level strategy.

If a sustainable forest management plan has been approved and a higher level plan comes into effect for the pilot project area, the participants, within 6 months after the effective date of the higher level plan, must submit to the regional manager and regional director

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an assessment of whether or not the sustainable forest management plan is consistent with the higher level plan, and
if the sustainable forest management plan is inconsistent with the higher level plan, a proposal for amending the sustainable forest management plan to make it consistent with the higher level plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional manager and regional director may approve a proposal submitted under subsection (1) if the regional manager and regional director are satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposal adequately addresses the areas of inconsistency, and
implementation of the proposal will address the areas of inconsistency in a timely manner.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the regional manager and regional director approve the proposal under subsection (2), the participants must implement that proposal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparation and submission of forest operations schedule

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a sustainable forest management plan has been approved, a participant is not required to prepare a forest development plan.
After a sustainable forest management plan has been approved, the participants may prepare and submit to the district manager a forest operations schedule that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identifies the areas in which timber harvesting and associated road construction is proposed by the participant,
is consistent with the sustainable forest management plan, and
complies with Schedule C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest operations schedule is effective on the date it is submitted to the district manager under subsection (2).
The participants must establish and maintain a public advisory group.
The participants must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm membership to the public advisory group and may confirm advisors to the public advisory group, and
publish annually a notice specifying the membership of the public advisory group.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The mandate of the public advisory group is to ensure that the participants' forest management decisions, as contained in the sustainable forest management plan, are made as a result of informed, inclusive and fair consultation with local people who are directly affected by or have an interest in sustainable forest management.
Without limiting subsection (1), the public advisory group must review

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with section 37, proposed sustainable forest management plans and amendments to sustainable forest management plans,
audits carried out under section 50, and
annual reports prepared under section 51.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The public advisory group must submit to the participants proposed policies and procedures concerning the operation of the public advisory group, including but not limited to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: frequency of meetings;
rules respecting conduct of meetings;
decision making;
communications;
replacement of representatives.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must consider any submission received under subsection (1) and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm the policies and procedures as submitted, or
amend the proposed policies and procedures and confirm them as amended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The public advisory group must follow any policies and procedures confirmed by the participants under subsection (2).
All meetings of the public advisory group are open to the public.
Membership of the public advisory group is on a voluntary basis with no remuneration payable to the representatives by the participants.
Expenses of the public advisory group are recoverable under and in accordance with policies and procedures referred to in subsection (2).
A participant must maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: records of its survey and inspection activities concerning the requirements under this regulation, and
each site level plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: until a declaration referred to in section 59 for the area to which the record or site level plan relates has been accepted by the district manager.
A participant, at the request of the district manager or of an official, must produce the records and plans referred to in subsection (1).

A participant must submit to and pay for periodic independent audits by a qualified auditor of the participant's compliance with this regulation and any matters specified in the sustainable forest management plan as being subject to audit, as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: once, on or before December 1, 2003;
at least once in every 2 year period after that date, subject to paragraph (c);
if a shorter period than 2 years, for the second and subsequent audits under this section, is specified in the sustainable forest management plan, at least once in each of those shorter periods.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified auditor must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conduct the audit in accordance with audit principles that are generally accepted for use in the forest industry,
provide the participant with opportunity to comment on the findings of the audit before they are finalized, and
submit a copy of the audit report to the participant and the regional manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participant may submit to the regional manager a response to the audit report and the regional manager must append the participant's response to the audit report.

On or before October 31, 2003, a participant must submit to the ministers a report, in compliance with subsection (3), concerning the operations carried out by the participant during the period beginning on the effective date of this regulation and ending on March 31, 2003.

On or before October 31 of each year after 2003, a participant must submit to the ministers a report, in compliance with subsection (3), concerning the operations carried out by the participant during the preceding fiscal year of the government.
A report under this section must contain the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a summary of the access management and timber harvesting carried out by the participant;

a summary of the reforestation activities carried out by the participant, including the regeneration method, year of establishment, estimated species composition at establishment, and estimated density at establishment;
a summary of the stand tending activities carried out by the participant;
a statement of the degree to which the landscape level strategies contained in the sustainable forest management plan were followed by the participant;
a summary of any variances given to the participant;
a summary of any amendments that were made to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a forest development plan, if, under section 71 (2) or (3), notice of the amendments was not required to be published, and
a forest operations schedule, if, under section 83 (2), (3) or (4), notice of the amendments was not required to be published;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a summary of any contraventions reported to the senior official by the participant;
a summary of any compliance and enforcement measures imposed on the participant by the government under Part 6 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must provide to the district manager and the public advisory group a copy of the report submitted under this section.
The ministers must make a copy of a report submitted under this section available to the public on request.
The regional manager must annually monitor the level of performance of each of the participants under this regulation by considering the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the audit reports submitted under section 50;
the annual reports submitted under section 51;
