information provided by the Forest Practices Board;
other information the regional manager considers relevant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional manager must make the result of the monitoring under subsection (1) available to the participant who is monitored.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evaluation of pilot project by government

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: From time to time the minister may assess the relative success of the pilot project at improving the regulatory framework of forest practices by evaluating, in the pilot project area, whether this regulation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provides equivalent protection to forest resources and resource features as are provided under the Act and the regulations,
is consistent with the preamble to the Act,
provides for adequate management and conservation of forest resources,
adequately provides for public review and comment respecting forest practices,
adequately provides for monitoring of the pilot project,
provides adequate public access to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: planning documents and assessments used in the pilot project, and
records that this regulation requires to be prepared, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is cost effective for one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: holders of agreements under the Forest Act;
the timber sales manager;
the government for administering forest practices.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 6 months after becoming a participant, each participant, including the timber sales manager, must provide to the regional manager a written estimate of the participant's current costs associated with carrying out forest practices under the Act and regulations, for comparison with the participant's current costs at the time of an evaluation under this section.
The minister may request relevant information from participants when carrying out an evaluation under subsection (1) and the participants must comply with that request in a timely manner.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Role of the Forest Practices Board

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The mandate of the Forest Practices Board extends to this regulation.

The Forest Practices Board may request a review of the approval of a sustainable forest management plan if the board believes that, in relation to the preparation of the plan or amendment, there has been a contravention of this regulation.
The Act and regulations apply to a review under subsection (2) as if the review were a review of a forest development plan approval.

If the Forest Practices Board requests a review of the approval of a forest development plan under section 128 of the Act, the Board must specify which portions of the forest development plan are subject to the request for review.
For the purposes of subsection (4), the Forest Practices Board must only specify those portions of the plan that are directly affected by the grounds for requesting the review.
Those portions of a forest development plan that are not subject to a request for review by the Forest Practices Board under section 128 of the Act remain in effect.

For the contravention of an enactment itemized in column 1 of Schedule G and described in column 2 of that item, the maximum penalty that may be levied under section 71 (2) of the Forest and Range Practices Act against a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence is the amount in column 3 of that item.

The following are prescribed as the considerations referred to in section 71 (5) (g) of the Forest and Range Practices Act for the minister before levying an administrative penalty referred to in Schedule G against a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the contravention was reported to the district manager by the participant or holder;
if the participant or holder carried out measures to mitigate the impact of the contravention, and the appropriateness, timeliness and success of those measures;
if there is any residual damage to the forest resources on the area in which the contravention occurred after the participant or holder carried out the measures referred to in paragraph (b);

if it is in the public interest to make a determination under section 7 (2) of the Forest and Range Practices Act, having considered all of the factors specified in section 71 (5) of the Forest and Range Practices Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the district manager determines that an area in a cutblock has sustained damage as a result of a forest practice, the district manager, by written notice, may direct that the participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence responsible for the damage take measures necessary to rehabilitate the area.

If, after the conclusion of timber harvesting in a cutblock, the district manager determines that a participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence has contravened section 28 (1) (f) (i) by not sustaining soil productivity, the district manager by written notice may direct that the participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence responsible take measures necessary to rehabilitate the area.
A notice under subsection (3) or (4) must include the rationale for the district manager's determination under that subsection.

A participant who receives a notice under subsection (3) or (4) may request a review and appeal of the district manager's determination, and Division 4 of Part 6 of the Forest and Range Practices Act applies to that review and appeal.

A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who contravenes section 28 (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a maximum penalty of $1 000 000, or to imprisonment for not more than 2 years, or to both.

A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who contravenes section 22 (1), (2) or (3), 28 (1), 30 (1) or (2), 31 (2) or 32 (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a maximum penalty of $500 000, or to imprisonment for not more than 2 years, or to both.

A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who contravenes section 24 (2), 29, 33, 42, 44 (1) or (3) or 60 (5) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a maximum penalty of $100 000, or to imprisonment for not more than one year, or to both.

A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence who contravenes section 31 (1), 49 (1) or (2), 50 (1), 51 (1) or 53 (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a maximum penalty of $5 000, or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or to both.
The maximum fine to which a person is liable on a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence under subsections (1) to (4) is double the amount set out in those subsections.
A participant must make copies of all relevant planning documents and associated assessments available at any reasonable time to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the district manager,
the public advisory group,
the Forest Practices Board, and
persons carrying out audits under this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The participants must ensure that a copy of any proposed sustainable forest management plan that has been submitted for approval is available for review by the public for the period required under section 38 during business hours at one or more of the business premises of the participants in the pilot project area.

A participant must ensure that the following information is reasonably available for review by the public during business hours at one or more of the business premises of the participant in the pilot project area:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of any approved sustainable forest management plan;
a copy of any active operational plans and related assessments of the participant that are in the pilot project area;
a copy of the most recent forest operations schedule, if any;
a copy of any audit report submitted under section 50 during the previous 5 years;
a copy of any annual report submitted under section 51 during the previous 5 years;
a copy of any compliance and enforcement determinations referred to in Division 3 of this Part in respect of the participant's performance in the pilot project area during the previous 5 years;
a copy of the maps referred to in section 5 and set out in Part A2 of Schedule A under the heading "Fort St. John Pilot Project Management Zone Maps".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant may enter into an agreement with another participant to assume the latter's obligations under the Act and this regulation in respect of a cutblock or road.
An agreement under subsection (1) is ineffective unless it is in writing and approved by the district manager.
A participant who in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a road,
timber harvesting activities in a cutblock, or
reforestation in a cutblock or in an identifiable portion of a cutblock,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: considers that the participant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has fully met the requirements, or
has met the requirements to the fullest extent practical

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: may submit to the district manager a written declaration to the effect set out in paragraph (d) or (e), whichever is applicable.
A participant must ensure that a written declaration under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identifies the roads or cutblocks,
specifies the requirements of the Act and the regulations to which the declaration applies, and
in the case of a declaration under subsection (1) (e), explains why the requirements were not fully met, giving particulars.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A written declaration submitted under subsection (1) by a participant to the district manager is sufficient evidence as of the date of its submission that the participant has met the requirements, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 15 months after receiving the written declaration, the district manager gives notice to the participant that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of a declaration under subsection (1) (d), the participant has not fully met the requirements, or
in the case of a declaration under subsection (1) (e), the participant has not met the requirements to the fullest extent practical, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the participant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the declaration, materially misrepresented or misstated a fact in relation to the requirement, or
omitted information from the declaration that the participant knew or ought to have known was material to determining whether the requirement had been fulfilled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before giving notice under subsection (3) (a) to a participant, the district manager

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must give the participant an opportunity to be heard, and
may require the participant to submit information that the district manager reasonably requires in order to make the determination.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of pilot project and transition

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by order may cancel the pilot project on a date, in this section called the "cancellation date", at least 2 years after the date on which the order is made, and
must give a copy of the order to each of the participants and holders of minor timber sale licences.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister makes an order under subsection (1), the Act and the regulations apply, effective on the cancellation date, in respect of the pilot project area, the participants and the holders of minor timber sale licences.
The minister may exempt participants or holders of minor timber sale licences from obligations under this regulation if the minister considers the exemption necessary or advisable for the purpose of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilitating the transition, after the date of an order under this section, from the application, in respect of the pilot project area, of the Act and this regulation to the application, in respect of the pilot project area, on and after the cancellation date, of the Act and the regulations, without this regulation, or
remedying difficulties encountered during the transition period between the date of the minister's order under subsection (1) and the cancellation date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption granted by the minister under subsection (3) may be of general or specific application and may be conditional or unconditional.
A participant or holder of a minor timber sale licence must comply with any condition imposed by the minister under subsection (4).

bcl:section.bcl:text: In items 1 to 24 of Schedule A:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: priority fish species means bull trout and grayling and includes those other species that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specified as red and blue listed species by the Ministry of Water, Land and Air Protection, and
referred to as red and blue listed species in publications of that ministry, including on the website maintained by that ministry;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: priority furbearing species means fisher, marten and lynx;
ROS means the Ministry of Forests Recreation Opportunity Spectrum;
stream flow regime means water quality, quantity and timing of flow;
visually sensitive areas includes travel and recreation corridors identified by the Ministry of Forests visual landscape inventory.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Fort St. John Pilot Project Management Zone Map

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest development plan must be consistent with any higher level plan that is in effect 4 months before the date the forest development plan is submitted for the district manager's approval, unless the higher level plan specifies otherwise.
A forest development plan must be signed and sealed by a professional forester.
A forest development plan must be signed by the participant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who prepares a forest development plan must provide detail for site-specific areas in the area under the plan if characteristics of that area result in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different operations being proposed,
similar operations being subject to different constraints, or
different operations being subject to different constraints.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that a forest development plan addresses an area sufficient in size to include all areas affected by the timber harvesting and road construction or modification operations proposed under the plan.

If the district manager determines that the area under a proposed forest development plan does not comply with subsection (1), the district manager, in a notice given to the participant, may specify the area that the plan must address.

A participant who receives a notice under subsection (2) may request a review and appeal of the district manager's determination, and Division 4 of Part 6 of the Act applies to that review and appeal.
The maximum size of a cutblock must not exceed 60 ha.
The maximum size for a cutblock specified under subsection (1) does not apply to a cutblock located in an area under a higher level plan if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the higher level plan specifies that cutblocks may be larger, or
the higher level plan specifies conditions precedent to approval of larger cutblock sizes and the district manager is satisfied that the conditions are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the district manager may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refuse to approve a forest development plan that includes a cutblock that complies with that subsection if the district manager is of the opinion that a cutblock smaller than that specified in subsection (1) is required

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for hydrological reasons,
to manage wildlife values,
to manage recreation or scenic values, or
for other similar reasons, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approve a forest development plan that includes a cutblock that is larger than that specified in subsection (1) if one or more of the following apply:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the harvesting is being carried out to recover timber that was damaged by fire, insects, wind or other similar events and, if possible, the cutblock incorporates structural characteristics of natural disturbance;
the silvicultural system proposed for the area

bcl:clause.bcl:text: is other than clearcut or seed tree, and
retains 40% or more of the pre-harvest basal area;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the district manager is of the opinion that the larger cutblock is designed to be consistent with the structural characteristics and the temporal and spatial distribution of natural openings.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Forest health assessment required before review of forest development plans
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before making a forest development plan available for review under section 73, a participant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: record and evaluate the occurrence of detected forest health factors currently causing damage or which may potentially cause damage in the area under the plan, and
conduct a forest health assessment, if required by the district manager, to determine the nature and extent of the forest health factors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Map and information requirements for all forest development plans

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that a forest development plan includes the following information for the area under the plan:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: forest cover;
the topography of the area, and the location of those streams, wetlands and lakes that are shown on forest cover maps or fish and fish habitat inventory maps or terrain resource inventory maps;
for terrain stability

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: one of the following:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: areas mapped on terrain stability hazard maps as having a moderate or high likelihood of landslides;
if no terrain stability hazard mapping has been done, areas identified on reconnaissance terrain stability maps as having unstable or potentially unstable terrain;
if no terrain stability hazard mapping or reconnaissance terrain stability mapping has been carried out, areas with a slope gradient greater than 60%, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any areas identified by the district manager as having unstable or potentially unstable terrain;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if required by the district manager, the operability line;
the following known items:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: protected areas;
designated areas under Part 13 of the Forest Act;
wilderness areas;
sensitive areas established in accordance with the Act;
subject to subsection (3), wildlife habitat areas;
forest ecosystem networks;
old growth management areas;
scenic areas;
ungulate winter ranges;
community water supply intakes and related water supply infrastructures;
fish streams;
riparian class of streams, wetlands and lakes;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following public utilities on Crown land:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: transmission lines;
gas and oil pipelines;
railways;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approximate location of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: construction of a road, including construction of a bridge or major culvert that is part of the road, if the road is proposed to be authorized under this regulation,
proposed replacement or addition of a bridge or major culvert, if the bridge or major culvert is part of a road authorized under this regulation,
construction of a bridge or major culvert proposed to be authorized under this regulation or agreement under the Forest Act, and
replacement or addition of a bridge or major culvert authorized under this regulation or agreement under the Forest Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and the year the work is proposed to take place if the timing is critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
the location of each road that has been included on the most recently approved forest development plan;
the forest operations for which road construction or modification is required, for operations other than harvesting;
for any proposed bridges, whether the bridge will be a temporary or permanent bridge;
with respect to an existing road that both provides access to the area and is required by the Act to be maintained by the participant, the following information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: its approximate location;
whether it is intended to be for seasonal use only;
a description or map of how it links up with a public road system, processing plant or log dump;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a list or map notation indicating the roads that must be maintained by the participant;
the following road deactivation operations that have been or are to be conducted by the participant on the area under the plan:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: roads that were permanently deactivated during the previous year;
roads that are currently deactivated to a temporary or semi-permanent level;
roads that are to be deactivated and the year the work is proposed to take place if the timing is critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
the level of deactivation of roads referred to in subparagraph (iii);
the types of vehicle usage, if any, that are proposed to be accommodated on the roads referred to in subparagraph (iii) after deactivation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the known location of roads that are proposed by other persons;
the known location of temporary or permanent barriers to vehicle access;
the approximate location of cutblocks proposed to achieve Category A status if the proposed forest development plan is approved;

for each Category A cutblock referred to in paragraph (p), specify for the purposes of section 35 and Schedule F if the cutblock is to be reforested as a coniferous area, a deciduous area or a mixedwood area;

the location of a cutblock that has been included as an approved Category A cutblock on the most recently approved forest development plan, and whether an authorization for the cutblock has been given under section 23;
the location of cutblocks that have been harvested, but are not yet greened-up and that are adjacent to cutblocks referred to in paragraph (p) or (r);
if significant risks to forest resources are recorded or disclosed by the forest health assessment, measures to reduce those risks that do not, themselves, cause new or significantly increased risks;
any applicable performance standards that are to apply for the purposes of Part 3 Division 5 and the associated Schedules;
the general objectives for riparian management zones, including the range of basal area retention by riparian class;
the known objectives for known ungulate winter ranges.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a participant is not required to include the information specified in that subsection for an area in a forest development plan in which only minor salvage operations will be carried out, unless the district manager, by written notice, requires some or all of that information, in which case the participant must comply with the requirements in that notice.

The location of any of the wildlife habitat areas referred to in subsection (1) (e) (v) must not be shown if the district manager or designated environmental official makes it known that the location of the wildlife habitat area is not to be included, in which case only the name of the identified wildlife protected by the wildlife habitat area must be included.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Category I cutblocks and roads for information purposes only

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A cutblock that does not meet the requirements for Category A, under section 69, may be shown on a forest development plan only as a Category I cutblock, and a Category I cutblock is for information purposes only, and is not part of the forest development plan.
A road may be shown as a Category I road on a forest development plan for information purposes only, and a Category I road is not part of the forest development plan.
A cutblock may be shown as a proposed Category A cutblock on a proposed forest development plan only if the proposed plan meets the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan includes, in the form of a map, for areas that are in or adjacent to the cutblock, the location of the following items, if the items may be impacted directly or indirectly by the cutblock:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: known resource features other than wildlife habitat features, domestic water supply intakes and archaeological sites;
known private property;
known licensed domestic water supply intakes and related water supply infrastructure;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan describes for the cutblock the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the year of harvest, if timing is critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
the location of any area of water that will be used as a helicopter or balloon log drop area;
whether or not the cutblock will be clearcut;
measures, if any, proposed to achieve higher level plan objectives;
measures, if any, for the management of known ungulate winter ranges;
whether the cutblock will be harvested by cable, aerial or ground based harvesting methods or a combination of those methods;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 103/2005, s. 8.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A cutblock may be shown as an approved Category A cutblock on a proposed forest development plan if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cutblock was included as an approved Category A cutblock on the most recently approved forest development plan, and
the information required under subsection (1) for the cutblock in that most recently approved plan is carried forward, without being updated, in the proposed plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: District manager may require referral of plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: By notice in writing, the district manager may require a participant who submits for approval a forest development plan or amendment to refer the proposed plan or amendment for the period required in the notice to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resource agencies specified in the notice by the district manager,
any government agency that is identified in the notice by the district manager, and
any person that may be materially affected by the proposed plan or amendment, and that is specified in the notice by the district manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who receives a notice under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the requirements of the notice,
review all written comments received during the referral period, and
make any revisions to the proposed plan or amendment that the participant considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who receives a notice under subsection (1) must submit to the district manager with the proposed plan or amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of each written comment received under subsection (2) in respect of the proposed plan or amendment, and
a summary of all revisions made to the proposed plan or amendment under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a forest development plan is referred to a resource agency, the agency may request that the participant who received the notice under subsection (1) send one or more of the assessments that are related to the plan to the resource agency within a reasonable time required in the notice, and the person must comply with the request.

A participant who is required to make a forest development plan available under subsection (1) (b) or (c) must make the assessments that are related to the plan, other than an archaeological impact assessment, available for review at the participant's place of business nearest to the area under the plan, or at another location specified by the district manager.

Before a participant submits a forest development plan or amendment for approval, the participant must publish in a newspaper a notice, in a form acceptable to the district manager, stating that the forest development plan is available for public review and comment.
Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if the district manager determines that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plan or amendment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: otherwise complies with this Schedule,
is necessary to enable measures to be taken to address an emergency, and
there is insufficient time to provide for review and comment for at least 10 days, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amendment

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: otherwise complies with this Schedule,
will adequately provide for managing and conserving the forest resources of British Columbia for the area to which it applies, and
does not materially change the objectives or results of the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amendment increases the size of a cutblock,
the amount of the increase does not exceed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 1 ha or 25% of the area of the cutblock, whichever is greater, if the cutblock is less than 20 ha before the increase, or
10 ha or 25% of the area of the cutblock, whichever is less, if the cutblock is at least 20 ha before the increase,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cutblock size remains consistent with section 65, and
none of the area being added to the cutblock as a result of the proposed amendment will result in harvesting within

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a riparian management zone of a stream that has a classification of S1, S2, S3 or S4,
a known forest ecosystem network,
a wildlife tree patch,
a known old growth management area, or
a known ungulate winter range.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Submitting forest development plan and assessments

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant required to publish a notice under section 71 must submit to the district manager a copy of the forest development plan or amendment in the form that will be made available for review under section 73

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at substantially the same time as a person first publishes the notice referred to in section 71, or
at any other time agreed to by the district manager and the participant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the request of the district manager, a participant who is responsible for a forest development plan must submit to the district manager a copy of any forest health assessment.

A participant who is required to publish a notice under section 71 must provide an opportunity to review a proposed forest development plan or amendment to members of the public interested in or affected by operations under the proposed plan or amendment in accordance with this Division.

If a forest health assessment has been completed, a participant who is required to provide an opportunity for review of the forest development plan or amendment, on the request of a person conducting a review of the plan under this section, must make the assessment available for viewing to that person to assist the review of the plan.

A participant who is required to provide a viewing of an assessment under subsection (2) must make it available at the participant's place of business nearest to the area under the plan or at another location specified by the district manager.
Subject to subsection (5), the opportunity for a review under subsection (1) must be for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a period of 60 days commencing on the date of the first publication referred to in section 71, except for a forest development plan or amendment referred to in paragraph (b), or

a period of at least 10 days, commencing on the date of the first publication referred to in section 71, if the entire forest development plan or amendment relates to an expedited major salvage operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (4) (a), by notice in writing given before the expiry of the 60 day period under subsection (4) (a) to a participant who is required to provide a review under this section, the district manager may extend the period for review under subsection (4) (a).

An opportunity for review provided to an interested or affected person under subsection (1) will be adequate only if, in the opinion of the district manager, the opportunity is commensurate with the nature and extent of that person's interest in the area under the plan and any right that person may have to use the area under the plan.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who reviews a forest development plan or amendment under this Part may submit comments in writing during the period allowed for review under section 73 to the participant who publishes a notice under section 71.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is required to publish a notice under section 71 must consider all comments received during the period for review under section 73 in relation to proposed Category A cutblocks and proposed road construction, modification and deactivation and make any revisions to the proposed plan or amendment that the person considers appropriate.
Despite subsection (1), neither the participant who is required to publish a notice under section 71 nor the district manager is required to consider or address a comment with respect to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cutblock that is included as part of the most recently approved forest development plan as a Category A cutblock, or
a road that has been included as part of a previously approved forest development plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Submitting a proposed forest development plan and comments
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who submits a forest development plan or amendment for approval must submit with the proposed forest development plan or amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the notices that were published under section 71 in respect of the proposed forest development plan or amendment,
a copy of each written comment received in respect of the proposed forest development plan or amendment, and
a summary of all revisions made to the proposed forest development plan or amendment under section 75 (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limited protection for cutblocks and roads

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a cutblock has been included as part of an approved forest development plan as a Category A cutblock, or a road has been included as part of an approved forest development plan, the district manager may refuse to approve a subsequently proposed forest development plan on the grounds that the part of the subsequently proposed forest development plan that is the cutblock or road does not comply with section 13, only if any of the following occurs in the period referred to in subsection (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an enactment is made or amended or a higher level plan is established or varied, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the enactment or higher level plan applies to the cutblock or road, and
the district manager is satisfied that the proposed cutblock or road makes the forest development plan inconsistent with that enactment or higher level plan;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a wildlife habitat area is established over any area of the proposed forest development plan, and the chief forester and the deputy minister of the Ministry of Water, Land and Air Protection have specified that the cutblock cannot be harvested as planned or the road cannot be located, constructed, modified or deactivated as planned;

catastrophic damage or destruction of timber occurs in the vicinity of the cutblock, as a result of which harvesting the cutblock, as planned, no longer adequately manages and conserves the forest resources;
a watershed assessment is completed for an area under the forest development plan, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the assessment reveals a condition that negatively affects the watershed,
either there was no previous watershed assessment, or there was a previous watershed assessment, but it did not reveal the condition, and
the recommendations in the current assessment specify that the cutblock should not be harvested as planned or the road should not be located, constructed, modified or deactivated as planned;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the timber harvesting or other operation for which the road was to provide access will not be proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The period referred to in subsection (1) is the period from 4 months before the forest development plan that is in effect was submitted for approval until 4 months before the proposed forest development plan is submitted for approval.

The district manager may not refuse to approve a forest development plan on the grounds that the part of the forest development plan that is a cutblock does not meet the requirements of that section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an authorization has been given for the cutblock under section 23, or
the cutblock has been included as part of an approved forest development plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The district manager may not refuse to approve a forest development plan on the grounds that the part of the forest development plan that is a road does not meet the requirements of section 13 if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an authorization has been given for the road under section 23, or
the road has been included as part of an approved forest development plan.

bcl:schedule.bcl:scheduletitle: Schedule C — Preparing Forest Operations Schedules

bcl:section.bcl:text: Nothing in this Schedule requires information to be included in a forest operations schedule if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information is included in a sustainable forest management plan in effect for the area, or
the sustainable forest management plan provides that the information is not required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest operations schedule must cover a period of at least 6 years unless the district manager consents to a shorter period.
A forest operations schedule must be consistent with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any higher level plan in effect 4 months before the date the schedule is submitted to the district manager unless the higher level plan specifies otherwise, and
the sustainable forest management plan in effect on the date that the schedule is submitted to the district manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A forest operations schedule must be signed and sealed by a professional forester.
A forest operations schedule must be signed by the participant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Map and information requirements for all forest operations schedules

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant must ensure that a forest operations schedule includes the following information for the area affected by the proposed timber harvesting and road construction or modification operations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: forest cover;
the topography of the area, and the location of those streams, wetlands and lakes that are shown on forest cover maps or fish and fish habitat inventory maps or terrain resource inventory maps;
the following known items:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: protected areas;
designated areas under Part 13 of the Forest Act;
wilderness areas;
established sensitive areas;
wildlife habitat areas, except in a case to which subparagraph (vi) of this paragraph applies;

the name of any identified wildlife protected by wildlife habitat areas if the district manager or a designated environment official makes it known that the location of the wildlife habitat area is not to be included;
forest ecosystem networks;
old growth management areas;
scenic areas;
ungulate winter ranges;
community water supply intakes and related water supply infrastructures;
fish streams;
riparian class of streams, wetlands and lakes;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following public utilities on Crown land:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: transmission lines;
gas and oil pipelines;
railways;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approximate location of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: proposed construction of a road, including construction of a bridge or major culvert that is part of the road,
proposed replacement or addition of a bridge or major culvert,
proposed construction of a bridge or major culvert, and
proposed replacement or addition of a bridge or major culvert authorized under this regulation or under an agreement under the Forest Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and the year in which the work is proposed to take place if the timing is critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
for any proposed bridges, whether the bridge will be a temporary or permanent bridge;
the following road deactivation operations that have been, or are to be conducted by the participant:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: roads that are currently deactivated to a temporary or semi-permanent level;
roads that are to be deactivated in the next 3 years and the year the work is proposed to take place if the timing is critical to the management of non-timber forest resources;
the level of deactivation of roads referred to in subparagraph (ii);
the types of vehicle usage, if any, that are proposed to be accommodated on the roads referred to in subparagraph (ii) after deactivation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the known location of temporary or permanent barriers to vehicle access;
the approximate location of cutblocks proposed that are not the subject of an authorization under section 23;
for each cutblock that is currently the subject of an authorization under section 23,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the approximate location of the cutblock, and
if the areas within the cutblock are to be reforested as coniferous areas, deciduous areas or mixedwood areas.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 103/2005, s. 10 (b).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a participant is not required to include the information specified in that subsection for an area in a forest operations schedule in which only minor salvage operations will be carried out, unless the district manager, by written notice, requires some or all of that information, in which case the participant must comply with that notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: District manager may require referral of forest operations schedule

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: By notice in writing, the district manager may require a participant who submits a forest operations schedule or amendment to refer the proposed schedule or amendment for the period required in the notice to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the resource agencies specified in the notice by the district manager,
any government agency that is identified in the notice by the district manager, and
any person that may be materially affected by the proposed schedule or amendment, and that is specified in the notice by the district manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who receives a notice under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the notice,
review all written comments received during the referral period, and
make any revisions to the proposed schedule or amendment that the participant considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who receives a notice under subsection (1) must submit to the district manager with the proposed schedule or amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of each written comment received under subsection (2) in respect of the proposed schedule or amendment, and
a summary of all revisions made to the proposed schedule or amendment under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a participant submits a forest operations schedule or amendment, the participant must publish a notice, in a form acceptable to the district manager, in a newspaper stating that the forest operations schedule is available for public review and comment.
Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if the district manager determines

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the forest operations schedule or amendment otherwise complies with this Schedule and is necessary to enable measures to be taken to address an emergency, and
that there is insufficient time to provide for review and comment for a period of at least 10 days.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if the district manager determines that the amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: otherwise complies with this Schedule,
will adequately provide for managing and conserving the forest resources of British Columbia for the area to which it applies, and
does not materially change the objectives or results of the schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if the amendment increases the size of a cutblock provided that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the increase does not exceed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 1 ha or 25% of the area of the cutblock, whichever is greater, if the cutblock is less than 20 ha before the increase, or
10 ha or 25% of the area of the cutblock, whichever is less, if the cutblock is at least 20 ha before the increase,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cutblock size remains consistent with the sustainable forest management plan, and
none of the area being added to the cutblock as a result of the proposed amendment will result in harvesting within

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a riparian management zone of a stream that has a classification of S1, S2, S3 or S4,
a known forest ecosystem network,
a wildlife tree patch,
a known old growth management area, or
a known ungulate winter range.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), notice is not required under that subsection if the district manager determines that it is not practicable to publish a notice, given the circumstances or conditions applicable to the area under an amendment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who is required to publish a notice under section 83 must submit to the district manager a copy of the forest operations schedule or amendment in the form that will be made available for review under section 85

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at substantially the same time as a person first publishes the notice referred to in section 83, or
at any other time agreed to by the district manager and the participant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is required to publish a notice under section 83 must provide an opportunity to review a proposed forest operations schedule or amendment to members of the public interested in or affected by operations under the proposed schedule or amendment in accordance with this Schedule.

The opportunity for a review of a forest operations schedule or of an amendment to a forest operations schedule by members of the public under subsection (1) begins on the date the notice is first published and ends 60 days after that date.
Despite subsection (2), the district manager may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: extend the period for review, if the district manager considers that a longer period is necessary to provide a person with an adequate opportunity for review and comment, commensurate with the nature and extent of the person's interest in the area under the forest operations schedule or any right that person has to use the area under that schedule, or

shorten the period for review, if the district manager considers that a shorter period will provide a person with an adequate opportunity for review and comment, commensurate with the nature and extent of the person's interest in the area under the forest operations schedule or any right that person has to use the area under that schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (2) and (3), the opportunity for review ends 10 days after the date the notice is first published if all or a substantial part of the timber to which the area identified in the forest operations schedule pertains

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is dead, infested with pests or otherwise damaged, or is required to be harvested to facilitate the removal of dead, infested or damaged timber, and
must be harvested expeditiously to prevent

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the spread of pests, or
a significant reduction in the economic value of the timber due to a deterioration in the quality of the timber.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who reviews a forest operations schedule or amendment under this Schedule may submit comments in writing during the period allowed for review under section 85 to the participant who publishes a notice under section 83.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who is required to publish a notice under section 83 must consider all comments received during the period for review under section 85 in relation to proposed cutblocks and proposed road construction, modification and deactivation and make any revisions to the proposed schedule or amendment that the participant considers appropriate.

Despite subsection (1), neither the participant who is required to publish a notice under section 83 nor the district manager is required to consider or address a comment with respect to a cutblock or road that is the subject of an authorization under section 23.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Submitting a proposed forest operations schedule and comments
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who submits a forest operations schedule or amendment must submit with the proposed forest operations schedule or amendment

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the notices that were published under section 83 in respect of the proposed forest operations schedule or amendment,
a copy of each written comment received in respect of the proposed forest operations schedule or amendment, and
a summary of all revisions made to the proposed forest operations schedule or amendment under section 87 (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Schedule active flood plain means the level area with alluvial soils adjacent to streams that is flooded by stream water on a periodic basis and is at the same elevation as areas showing evidence of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: flood channels free of terrestrial vegetation,
recently rafted debris or fluvial sediments newly deposited on the surface of the forest floor or suspended on trees or vegetation, or
recent scarring of trees by material moved by flood waters.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Streams that are not fish streams are of the following riparian classes:

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each riparian class referred to in section 90, the minimum riparian reserve zone width and riparian management zone width on each side of the stream are as follows:

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), if a stream has, on average, over a one km length,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a channel width of 100 m or greater, and
an active flood plain width of 100 m or greater,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the stream has no riparian reserve zone, but does have a riparian management zone of 100 m or the width of the active flood plain, whichever is greater.

Despite subsection (1), for any stream the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may vary the width of the riparian reserve zone or riparian management zone referred to in that subsection.
Despite subsection (2), for a stream referred to in that subsection, the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a riparian reserve zone, and
specify the width of that zone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The riparian reserve zone extends the widths specified in subsection (1), (3) or (4) from the edge of the stream channel bank.
The riparian management zone extends from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the outer edge of the riparian reserve zone, or
if there is no riparian reserve zone, the edge of the stream channel bank

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the top of the inner gorge of the stream, or
whichever of the following is the greater:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the widths specified in subsection (1), (3) or (4);
the outer edge of any

bcl:clause.bcl:text: active flood plain, or
wetland that is less than 1 ha in size and is within the widths of the riparian management area specified in subsection (1), (3) or (4).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Wetlands are of the following riparian classes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: W1 if it is greater than 5 ha in size;
W3 if it is between one ha and 5 ha in size;
W5 if the area consists of 2 or more individual wetlands with overlapping riparian management areas and the combined size of the wetlands is 5 ha or larger.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minimum widths of riparian reserve zones and riparian management zones for wetlands

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each riparian class referred to in section 92, the minimum reserve zone and riparian management zone width is the following:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: W1
W3
W5

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), upland terrain in a wetland larger than 1 000 ha has no riparian reserve zone or riparian management zone.
Despite subsection (1), for any wetland or portion of a wetland, the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may vary the widths referred to in that subsection.
Despite subsection (2), for a wetland referred to in that subsection or a portion of that wetland, the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a riparian reserve zone or a riparian management zone, and
specify the widths of those zones.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The riparian reserve zone extends the widths specified in subsection (1), (3) or (4) from the edge of the wetland.
The riparian management zone extends the widths specified in subsection (1), (3) or (4) from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the outer edge of the riparian reserve zone, or
if there is no riparian reserve zone, the edge of the wetland.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Lakes are of the following riparian classes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: L1 if the lakes are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: greater than 5 ha in size, or
designated by the district manager;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: L3 if the lakes are between one ha and 5 ha in size.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minimum widths of riparian reserve zones and riparian management zones for lakes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lake of a riparian class of L1 has a riparian reserve zone width of 10 m, unless otherwise specified by the district manager.
A lake of a riparian class of L3 has a riparian reserve zone of 0 m and a riparian management zone width of 30 m.
Despite subsections (1) and (2), a lake greater than 1 000 ha has no riparian reserve zone.

Despite subsections (1) and (2), for any lake or portion of a lake, the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may vary the widths referred to in those subsections.
Despite subsection (3), for a lake referred to in that subsection or a portion of that lake, the district manager, with the agreement of a designated environmental official, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a riparian reserve zone, and
specify the width of that zone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The riparian reserve zone extends the widths specified in subsection (1), (2), (4) or (5) from the edge of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the natural boundary of the lake, or
the wetland that is contiguous to the lake if the wetland is up to 5 ha in size.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The riparian management zone extends from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the outer edge of the riparian reserve zone, or
if there is no riparian reserve zone, the edge of the wetland.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An area is greened-up if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 75% of the previously harvested cutblock area meets the minimum stocking requirements specified in Schedule F, and
the average height of the tallest 10% of the trees is a minimum of 3 m.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Harvesting adjacent to areas that are not greened-up
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 28 (1) (b) (iv), a participant may harvest a cutblock that is adjacent to a previously harvested cutblock that is not greened-up, if the requirements in any of the following paragraphs are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the previously harvested cutblock was harvested under a licence to cut or a Christmas tree permit;
a partial cut silvicultural system is used that retains trees in a uniform distribution throughout the cutblock to be harvested, and 40% or more of the pre-harvest basal area will be retained;
the total area of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the cutblock to be harvested, and
the harvested cutblocks that are not greened-up and that are adjacent to the cutblock to be harvested

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not exceed the maximum size for cutblocks specified or varied under Schedule B;
the harvesting of the cutblock is necessary to achieve established visual quality objectives;

for areas subject to a forest development plan, the resultant opening has been authorized by the district manager, in a written notice given to the person, on the grounds that it will be consistent with the structural characteristics and the temporal and spatial distribution of natural openings;

the proposed harvesting will recover timber that was damaged by fire, insects, wind or other similar events and, if possible, the cutblock to be harvested incorporates structural characteristics of natural disturbance;
the resultant opening will be consistent with the patch and seral stage targets identified in a sustainable forest management plan.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: BWBS means the boreal white and black spruce biogeoclimatic zone;

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When determining type of site for the purposes of Table A, the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minimum strata size that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a 2 ha contiguous area, or
20% of the cutblock area if the cutblock is less than 10 ha;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for strata that do not meet the minimum requirements of paragraph (a), the stocking requirements of the largest adjacent strata in the cutblock apply;

despite paragraph (b), if a strata does not meet the requirements of paragraph (a) but the professional forester who prepared the site level plan for the area is of the opinion that the area in the cutblock in which reforestation is required is a complex of different types of sites interspersed, then the stocking requirements for the complex is the number of trees per hectare determined by the following procedure:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: first, estimate the amount of area in each type of site;
second, for each type of site, multiply the amount of area of that type by the stocking requirement for that type of site determined in accordance with Table A;
third, add the total number of well spaced trees required for all types of sites as determined under subparagraph (ii);
fourth, divide the total number of trees required for the complex by the area of the cutblock.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who carries out planting to reforest an area must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use only seedlots or vegetative lots collected and registered in accordance with the Tree Cone, Seed and Vegetative Material Regulation,
use the best genetic quality source available,
store tree seeds with the ministry,

if the participant knows or should know of forest health concerns that affect the health of the species of trees that are required by the prescription, use only naturally or genetically improved resistant seed sources, seedlings or vegetative propagules if they are available,
not exceed the limits for seed or vegetative material transfer specified in the Ministry of Forests' publication "Seed and Vegetative Material Guidebook", as amended from time to time, and
keep a record of the registration numbers of the seedlots or vegetative lots used and the locations in which they are planted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of livestock in site preparation
bcl:section.bcl:text: A participant who uses livestock for site preparation or brush control must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that all necessary measures are taken to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: minimize conflict between livestock and animals that could prey on livestock,
prevent transmission of disease from livestock to wildlife, and
maintain the health of livestock,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish a buffer zone on the area if required to do so by a designated environmental official and prevent livestock from entering the zone,
notify a designated forest official and a designated environmental official before the arrival of the livestock, and
use livestock only if they have been inspected and certified as required by the Minister of Agriculture and Lands.
